replies.bodyText: Yes, but the Java configuration based API is for new config items generally. The code looks at ozone-default.xml and also Java based configuration classes and creates a master list for the default xml during assembly.
replies.author: avijayanhwx

replies.bodyText:
I am 100% happy with the answer...
... but as @anuengineer is not here I feel the responsibility to decorate pull requests with random external literature. 😄
Slow migration to Java based configuration API can happen at any time:

THE BOY SCOUTS HAVE A RULE: “Always leave the campground cleaner than you found it.” If you find a mess on the ground, you clean it up regardless of who might have made it. You intentionally improve the environment for the next group of campers. (Actually, the original form of that rule, written by Robert Stephenson Smyth Baden-Powell, the father of scouting, was “Try and leave this world a little better than you found it.”)


What if we followed a similar rule in our code: “Always check a module in cleaner than when you checked it out”? Regardless of who the original author was, what if we always made some effort, no matter how small, to improve the module? What would be the result?

https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/97-things-every/9780596809515/ch08.html
(Again, It's fine with me as is, I do the same. I skip the migration when it makes the patch harder to understand. But I never skip to add funny comments... 😉 )

replies.bodyText: Yes, but internally, I found that it becomes uppercase in the DB metadata. Hence, if I keep it as "recon", I have to do .toUpperCase() in Jooq code gen setSchemaName for it to find our classes.
